1 \defgroup session-schedule Session Schedule
2 \ingroup scheduler
3 
4 \details
5 
6 Session Scheduler exposes the OnixS::B3::BOE::Scheduling::SessionSchedule class to define
7 the interval of time during which session must be connected on (active).
8 
9 \section schedule-definition Defining Session Connection Time-frames
10 
11 The OnixS::B3::BOE::Scheduling::SessionSchedule constructor initializes the session schedule
12 for all supported cases that are based on the given parameters.
13 
14 The first two parameters (`firstDay` and `lastDay`) define the
15 activity week. During these days the session will be always connected at logon time
16 and disconnected at logout time.
17 
18 \note
19 All combinations of values for `firstDay` and `lastDay` parameters
20 are supported. It is possible for the `firstDay` parameter value to be greater than
21 value of `lastDay` parameter. In such a case, schedule will cross the end of the week
22 and continue till `lastDay`. If `firstDay` and `lastDay`
23 parameters are of the same value, then length (number of days) of the activity week depends on
24 the values of `logonTime` and `logoutTime` parameters. In particular,
25 if `logonTime` is less than `logoutTime`, then the activity week will
26 equal to a single day. However, if `logonTime` is greater than `logoutTime`,
27 then the activity week will equal to seven days (first logon will be performed at logon time on the first
28 day, last logout will be performed at logout time a week later).
29 
30 The `logonTime` and `logoutTime` parameters respectively define
31 time of logon and logout for the session for each activity day.
32 
33 By default, the Scheduler uses the local time to determine when a session should be connected/disconnected in accordance
34 with the Schedule.
35 In this case, for different time zones, there is a need to create/configure different schedules.
36 However, you can use OnixS::B3::BOE::Scheduling::SessionScheduler::utcTimeUsage option for switching local time to UTC
37 time usage.
38 In this case, the Scheduler will use the UTC time and you can create/configure the one schedule using the UTC time for
39 all time zones.
40 This can be useful when you deploy your application in different time zones and you need the same behavior of the
41 Scheduler in all time zones by creating only one schedule.
42

47 \section advanced-schedule-manipulations Advanced Cases
48 
49 The schedule construction is simplified with parameters to satisfy the most common use cases.
50 In particular, it exposes only the ability to define logon and logout time equal for all the
51 activity days. However, sometimes it is necessary to define different logon and logout times
52 for different days. OnixS::B3::BOE::Scheduling::SessionSchedule provides this ability through the
53 OnixS::B3::BOE::Scheduling::SessionSchedule::logonTime and
54 OnixS::B3::BOE::Scheduling::SessionSchedule::logoutTime members.
55 
56 Both OnixS::B3::BOE::Scheduling::SessionSchedule::logonTime and
57 OnixS::B3::BOE::Scheduling::SessionSchedule::logoutTime members return and update
58 logon and logout time appropriately for a given day of the week. Modifying entries
59 of these collections give the more advanced capability to define different
60 logon/logout time for different days.
61
